newsitem.title: USA: IRS says muni electric output rules a top priority.
newsitem.headline: IRS says muni electric output rules a top priority.

text.p: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug 4 (Reuter - The Internal Revenue Service's top priority in the municipal bond area is to issue private activity rules for electric and gas output facilities, an IRS official told bond lawyers Friday.
"Our first priority in terms of regulation projects continues to be output regulations," said Michael Bailey, counsel to IRS' assistant chief counsel for financial institutions and products.
Bailey spoke at a meeting of the American Bar Association's committee on tax exempt financing.
Bailey said Donald Lubick, Treasury assistant secretary for tax policy, met with public power and California officials last week to discuss their fears about private-use curbs on tax-exempt bonds.
Groups are concerned that the restrictions will limit the ability of municipal utilities to compete in an electric power market hurdling toward deregulation.

"There was a meeting held by the assistant secretary last week with a number of industry groups who expressed their concerns (about) how transactions entered into under the new open access regime will be treated under the private activity bond rules," Bailey said.
Treasury officials said they would try to respond to those concerns "immediately," Bailey said.
"The highest levels at Treasury know about the concerns that many municipaLly-owned utilities have about open access," Bailey said.
IRS proposed private activity bond regulations in late 1994, including special rules for electric and gas generation, transmission and distribution facilities.
But in the final package issued January 10, 1997, IRS said it was delaying final standards for output facilities until a later date.
Bailey said work on the output facility rules has priority over other pending muni bond standards, including rules for so-called mixed-use facilities and for bond refundings.
"It's certainly the case that we may move ahead with the output regulations first if that's what's needed to get the project done promptly," Bailey said.
